subject: Re: How to test console output?
msgSnippet: ... to ... to ... not ... Just ... to ... only ... creating the extra StringWriter every time, anyway. ... new one each time. ... should be its own method. You
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
>
> >So said jxingtang on 2003-07-30 --------------------
> >> >A further question for StringWriter manipulation. Since I have
to
> >> >test several methods with console output which share the same
> >> >StringWriter wrapped in the PrinterWriter. The problem is how
to
> >> >clean up the buffer after one test case. flush() method seems
not
> >> >work as expected.
> >>
> >> Why do you have to share the same StringWriter for each test?
Just
> >create a new one.
>
> >I have found a way to solve the problem. I calls the getBuffer()to
> >get the string buffer from the StringWriter and delete its content.
> >
> >The reason for me to share the StringWriter is that I do not want
to
> >construct a new class instance being tested for each method. I
only
> >construct on in setUp(). Here are of my code snippets.
>
> I have news for you: setUp() is called for each test. You are
creating the extra StringWriter every time, anyway.
>
> Don't worry about it. These aren't performance tests. Just create a
new one each time.
>
> >public class MyClass
> >{
> > private PrintWriter MyWriter;
> >
> > // Constructor for production release
> > public MyClass()
> > {
> > MyWriter = new PrintWriter( System.out );
> > }
> >
> > // Constructor for Junit testing
> > public MyClass( PrintWriter pw )
> > {
> > MyWriter = pw;
> > }
> >
> > public void DumpOutput( Vector params )
> > {
> > // Clip ...
> > }
> >};
> >
> >public class MyClassTest extends TestCase
> >{
> > private MyClass MyTestObj = null;
> >
> > private StringWriter StrWriter = null;
> >
> > // Clip ...
> >
> > protected void setUp()
> > {
> > StrWriter = new StringWriter();
> > PrintWriter prWriter = new PrintWriter( StrWriter );
> > TestObj = new MyClass( prWriter );
> > }
> >
> > public DumpOutputTest()
> > {
> > Vector testParams = new Vector();
> > // Testcase 1
> > testParams.addElement( "A" );
> > testParams.addElement( "B" );
> > testParams.addElement( "C" );
> >
> > TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
> >
> > String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
> >
> > // Code to evaluate outStr
> > // Clip ....
> >
> > // Clean buffer of StringWriter
> > StringBuffer sbuff = StrWriter.getBuffer();
> > sbuff.delete( 0, outStr.length());
> >
> > // Testcase 2
> > testParams.addElement( "X" );
> > testParams.addElement( "Y" );
> > testParams.addElement( "Z" );
> >
> > TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
> >
> > String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
> >
> > // Code to evaluate outStr
> > // Clip ....
> > }
> >
> > // Clip ...
> >};
> >
> >Please give your valuable comments for my further correction and
> >improvements.
>
> Why are you writing multiple tests in a single method? Each test
should be its own method. You defeat the point of JUnit by using it
this way.
>

Well, I use Eclipse with JUB plugin to automatically generate Junit
test class. For each method being tested, only one corresponding
method in the test class will be generated. However, for each method
being tested, there are quite a few test cases. Do I need to create a
new test method for each test case? Given the above code snippet as
example, do I need to separate DumpOutputTest into DumpOuputTestOne()
and DumpOutputTestTwo()?

Thanks a lot for your further comments!
